question: Which of the following hematological disease is associated with periodontal disease?
prompt:
Which of the following hematological disease is associated with periodontal disease?A)AIDS
B)Hypophosphatesia
C)Wegener's granulomatosis
D)Histocytosis
output0: Periodontal disease is associated with AIDS, as people with HIV/AIDS are more susceptible to periodontal infections due to their compromised immune system.
output1: Hypophosphatemia, or low levels of phosphate in the blood, is a condition that has been associated with periodontal disease. This is because phosphate is an essential nutrient for the development and maintenance of healthy bones and teeth, and a deficiency in phosphate can lead to weakened bones and teeth, making them more susceptible to periodontal disease.
output2: Wegener's granulomatosis is a hematological disease that can cause periodontal disease. This disease is characterized by the formation of granulomas, which can lead to inflammation and damage to the periodontal tissues.
output3: Histocytosis is a condition in which there is an overproduction of histocytes, a type of white blood cell. This condition is associated with an increased risk of developing periodontal disease.

question: Most common germ cell tumor of ovary is ?
prompt:
Most common germ cell tumor of ovary is ?A)Dysgerminoma
B)Serous cystadenoma
C)Yolk sac tumor
D)Dermoid cyst
output0: Dysgerminoma is the most common germ cell tumor of the ovary, accounting for approximately 50% of all ovarian germ cell tumors. It is a malignant tumor that usually affects prepubertal girls.
output1: Serous cystadenoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor of the ovary, accounting for approximately 50% of all ovarian germ cell tumors. It is a malignant tumor that develops from the cells that line the ovary.
output2: Yolk sac tumor is the most common germ cell tumor of the ovary, accounting for approximately 50% of all ovarian germ cell tumors. It is a type of teratoma that contains a variety of tissue types, including skin, hair, and gastrointestinal structures.
output3: Dermoid cysts are the most common type of germ cell tumor of the ovary. They are benign tumors that develop from immature cells that have not yet differentiated into specific tissues.

question:
A 45-year-old G2P2 presents with episodes of urgency accompanied by an involuntary passage of urine. These symptoms take place during the day and night. The symptoms are not linked with physical exertion, laughing, or coughing. Her occupation does not involve weight lifting, but she says that sometimes it is very stressful for her. She denies any other genitourinary symptoms. She had  1 vaginal delivery and 1 cesarean section. She does not have a history of genitourinary or neurologic disorders. The weight is 91 kg (200.6 lb) and the height is 172 cm (5 ft 60 in). The vital signs are as follows: blood pressure, 128/75 mmHg; heart rate, 77/min; respiratory rate, 13/min; and temperature, 36.6℃ (97.9℉). The physical examination shows no abdominal masses and no costovertebral angle or suprapubic tenderness. On gynecologic examination, there are no vulvar lesions. The external urethral orifice appears normal. A Q-tip test is negative. The cervix is normally positioned, non-tender, movable, and without visible lesions. The uterus is not enlarged and the ovaries are not palpable. A urinalysis, urine culture, and ultrasound examination of the bladder were all normal. Cystometric studies show the following findings:
  Measured value Normal range
Residual volume 10 ml < 50 ml
Sensation-of-fullness volume 190 ml 200–225 ml
Urge-to-void volume 700 ml 400–500 ml
Involuntary contractions present absent
Which of the following treatment strategies would be most appropriate for this patient?
correct_answer: Start her on a muscarinic antagonist
options: A)Instillation of the urethral mesh sling
D)Start her on a muscarinic antagonist
prompt:
A 45-year-old G2P2 presents with episodes of urgency accompanied by an involuntary passage of urine. These symptoms take place during the day and night. The symptoms are not linked with physical exertion, laughing, or coughing. Her occupation does not involve weight lifting, but she says that sometimes it is very stressful for her. She denies any other genitourinary symptoms. She had  1 vaginal delivery and 1 cesarean section. She does not have a history of genitourinary or neurologic disorders. The weight is 91 kg (200.6 lb) and the height is 172 cm (5 ft 60 in). The vital signs are as follows: blood pressure, 128/75 mmHg; heart rate, 77/min; respiratory rate, 13/min; and temperature, 36.6℃ (97.9℉). The physical examination shows no abdominal masses and no costovertebral angle or suprapubic tenderness. On gynecologic examination, there are no vulvar lesions. The external urethral orifice appears normal. A Q-tip test is negative. The cervix is normally positioned, non-tender, movable, and without visible lesions. The uterus is not enlarged and the ovaries are not palpable. A urinalysis, urine culture, and ultrasound examination of the bladder were all normal. Cystometric studies show the following findings:
  Measured value Normal range
Residual volume 10 ml < 50 ml
Sensation-of-fullness volume 190 ml 200–225 ml
Urge-to-void volume 700 ml 400–500 ml
Involuntary contractions present absent
Which of the following treatment strategies would be most appropriate for this patient?A)Instillation of the urethral mesh sling
B)Topical estrogen therapy
C)Augmentation cystoplasty
D)Start her on a muscarinic antagonist
output0: Based on the patient's history and physical examination findings, the most appropriate treatment strategy for this patient would be instillation of the urethral mesh sling. This is because the patient's symptoms of urgency and involuntary passage of urine are consistent with a diagnosis of urinary incontinence, which can be effectively treated with a urethral sling. Additionally, the patient's symptoms are not related to physical exertion or other factors that might indicate a different treatment approach.
output1: Topical estrogen therapy is the most appropriate treatment strategy for this patient because she has symptoms of urgency and stress urinary incontinence, which are common in postmenopausal women. Estrogen deficiency is a known contributor to these symptoms, and topical estrogen therapy can help to alleviate them. Additionally, estrogen therapy has been shown to improve the symptoms of overactive bladder, which is also a common symptom in this patient population.
output2: The patient's symptoms of urgency and involuntary passage of urine are most consistent with overactive bladder, a condition that is often treated with augmentation cystoplasty. This surgical procedure involves enlarging the bladder by inserting a mesh sling. The cystometric studies also support this diagnosis, as the patient has a low sensation-of-fullness volume and a high urge-to-void volume. Additionally, the patient's symptoms are not relieved by medications such as anticholinergics, which are often used to treat overactive bladder.
output3: The patient's symptoms of urgency and involuntary passage of urine are consistent with overactive bladder (OAB). Muscarinic antagonists, such as tolterodine or oxybutynin, are commonly used to treat OAB. These medications work by blocking the action of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter that stimulates the bladder muscle to contract. By reducing the bladder contractions, the patient's symptoms of urgency and incontinence should improve.

question: I-pill is used when ?
prompt:
I-pill is used when ?A)Accidental sexual exposure
B)OCP forgotten
C)Of choice in young
D)All of the above
output0: I-pill is a form of emergency contraception that can be used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected sex or contraceptive failure. It is also sometimes used in cases of accidental sexual exposure.
output1: I-pill is used when an individual has forgotten to take their oral contraceptive pill (OCP). It is a single dose of levonorgestrel that can be taken up to 72 hours (3 days) after the usual time of taking the OCP, to prevent pregnancy.
output2: I-pill is a form of emergency contraception that can be used by women of all ages, but it is most commonly used by young women who have had unprotected sex or have experienced contraceptive failure. It is also sometimes used by women who are at risk of pregnancy due to sexual assault or rape.
output3: I-pill is a medication that is used in a variety of situations, including accidental sexual exposure, forgotten OCP use, and as a method of choice for young women. Therefore, the correct answer is D)All of the above.

question: Long term complication of infants born to I.D.D.M mother AJE –
prompt:
Long term complication of infants born to I.D.D.M mother AJE –A)DM
B)Ketotic hypoglycemia
C)Obesity
D)Blindness
output0: Infants born to mothers with IDDM have a higher risk of developing DM themselves, as well as other complications such as blindness and obesity. However, the long-term complication that is most commonly associated with IDDM in infants is DM.
output1: Infants born to mothers with IDDM (insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus) are at risk of developing ketotic hypoglycemia, a condition characterized by low blood sugar levels and the presence of ketones in the blood. This can occur when the mother's high blood sugar levels during pregnancy cross the placenta and cause the baby's blood sugar levels to become too high, leading to the production of ketones.
output2: Children born to mothers with IDDM (insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus) have a higher risk of developing obesity in later childhood and adolescence. This is due to the fact that maternal diabetes can lead to fetal overgrowth and programming of the fetus's metabolism, which can predispose the child to obesity later in life.
output3: Infants born to mothers with IDDM have a higher risk of developing blindness due to the maternal diabetes. This is because high blood sugar levels can cause damage to the blood vessels in the retina, leading to vision loss and potentially blindness.

question: In a 19 years old patient, with a swelling over the left angle of the mandible, temperature of 38°C and negative history of trauma, one should suspect:
prompt:
In a 19 years old patient, with a swelling over the left angle of the mandible, temperature of 38°C and negative history of trauma, one should suspect:A)Spontaneous fracture of the mandible
B)Pericoronal infection
C)Mumps
D)Sjogren's syndrome
output0: The symptoms described, such as swelling over the left angle of the mandible, temperature of 38°C, and negative history of trauma, are consistent with a spontaneous fracture of the mandible. This is a common condition in young adults, and is often caused by a combination of factors such as hormonal changes, increased activity levels, and poor nutrition.
output1: The symptoms of swelling over the left angle of the mandible, temperature of 38°C, and negative history of trauma are consistent with a pericoronal infection, which is an infection of the gum tissue around the molar teeth. The patient's age of 19 years also supports this diagnosis, as pericoronal infections are more common in young adults.
output2: The patient's symptoms of swelling over the left angle of the mandible, temperature of 38°C, and negative history of trauma are consistent with a viral infection such as mumps. Mumps is a common cause of swelling in the salivary glands, and can cause symptoms such as fever and swelling in the face, neck, and jaw.
output3: The patient's symptoms of swelling over the left angle of the mandible, temperature of 38°C, and negative history of trauma are consistent with Sjogren's syndrome, an autoimmune disorder that affects the exocrine glands, including the salivary glands.

question: Patient with pulmonary fibrosis. Which antiarrhythmic drug should not be given
prompt:
Patient with pulmonary fibrosis. Which antiarrhythmic drug should not be givenA)Amiodarone
B)Flecainide
C)Iv ibutilide
D)lidocaine
output0: Amiodarone is contraindicated in patients with pulmonary fibrosis because it can cause arrhythmias and increase the risk of cardiac complications. Therefore, it should not be given to patients with this condition.
output1: Flecainide is a Class 1C antiarrhythmic drug, which is contraindicated in patients with pulmonary fibrosis. This is because Flecainide can cause a rare but potentially fatal side effect called pulmonary toxicity, which can worsen the condition of patients with pulmonary fibrosis. Therefore, it is not recommended to give Flecainide to patients with pulmonary fibrosis.
output2: Iv ibutilide is contraindicated in patients with pulmonary fibrosis, as it can increase the risk of ventricular arrhythmias and worsen the patient's condition.
output3: Lidocaine is a local anesthetic and should not be used in patients with pulmonary fibrosis, as it can cause respiratory depression.

question: Lactate, alanine and glycerol have in common:
options: B)Be intermediaries of the citric acid cycle (or tricarboxylic acid cycle).
C)To be final products of aerobic glycolysis.
prompt:
Lactate, alanine and glycerol have in common:A)Be substrates of mitochondrial beta-oxidation.
B)Be intermediaries of the citric acid cycle (or tricarboxylic acid cycle).
C)To be final products of aerobic glycolysis.
D)Be non-glucidic precursors for gluconeogenesis.
output0: Lactate, alanine, and glycerol are all substrates of mitochondrial beta-oxidation, which is a process that occurs in the mitochondria and involves the oxidation of these substrates to produce energy in the form of ATP.
output1: Lactate, alanine, and glycerol are all intermediates of the citric acid cycle (also known as the tricarboxylic acid cycle). They are not final products of aerobic glycolysis, and they are not substrates of mitochondrial beta-oxidation. Additionally, they are not non-glucidic precursors for gluconeogenesis.
output2: Lactate, alanine, and glycerol are all final products of aerobic glycolysis, which is the process by which glucose is broken down to produce energy in the presence of oxygen. These compounds are not substrates or intermediaries of any other metabolic pathways.
output3: Lactate, alanine, and glycerol are all non-glucidic precursors for gluconeogenesis. This means that they can be used as building blocks to synthesize glucose in the liver.

question: A 10-year-old boy is having sensory neural deafness. He showed no improvement with conventional hearing aids. Most appropriate management is:
prompt:
A 10-year-old boy is having sensory neural deafness. He showed no improvement with conventional hearing aids. Most appropriate management is:A)Bone conduction hearing aids
B)Fenestration
C)Stapes fixation
D)Cochlear implant
output0: Bone conduction hearing aids are the most appropriate management for a 10-year-old boy with sensory neural deafness, as they bypass the outer and middle ear and directly stimulate the inner ear. This approach is often used when conventional hearing aids are not effective.
output1: Fenestration is the most appropriate management for a 10-year-old boy with sensory neural deafness who has not improved with conventional hearing aids. This is because fenestration involves the creation of a hole in the bone covering the cochlea, which allows the sound waves to reach the inner ear directly and bypass the outer hair cells that are damaged or non-functional. This can help improve hearing in cases where the hearing loss is due to damage to the outer hair cells.
output2: Stapes fixation is the most appropriate management for a 10-year-old boy with sensory neural deafness who has not shown improvement with conventional hearing aids. This technique involves fixing the stapes bone in the middle ear, which helps to improve hearing.
output3: A cochlear implant is the most appropriate management for a 10-year-old boy with sensory neural deafness who has not shown improvement with conventional hearing aids. Cochlear implants bypass the damaged part of the ear and directly stimulate the auditory nerve, allowing the child to hear sounds and speech.

question: Pulp mummification is indicated in:
correct_answer: Traumatic exposure of a vital tooth
options: B)Deep caries on a symptomatic vital tooth
C)Traumatic exposure of a vital tooth
D)Traumatic exposure of a vital tooth with open wide apex
prompt:
Pulp mummification is indicated in:A)Non-vital tooth
B)Deep caries on a symptomatic vital tooth
C)Traumatic exposure of a vital tooth
D)Traumatic exposure of a vital tooth with open wide apex
output0: Pulp mummification is a technique used to preserve the vital pulp tissue in non-vital teeth. It is indicated in cases where the tooth is not salvageable, but the pulp tissue is still viable. This technique is not recommended for vital teeth, as it can cause more harm than good.
output1: Pulp mummification is indicated in cases of deep caries on symptomatic vital teeth, as it can help to prevent the spread of infection and save the tooth.
output2: Pulp mummification is indicated in cases of traumatic exposure of a vital tooth. This is a technique used to save the tooth and prevent infection.
output3: Pulp mummification is indicated in cases of traumatic exposure of a vital tooth with open wide apex, as it helps to prevent the spread of infection and promote healing.
